Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 11:33AM beegirl wrote: jacquib: I was so saddened by your message and want to urge you to hang in there. I hope that there is a cancer resource center at or near where you'll be doing rads so that you can find some support and meet others going through this. I've found two support groups through the hospital that have been really helpful. I would hope that if other BC survivors know of your predicament being there by yourself they'll find ways to provide support. If you have a religious affiliation, you might also find local support through those channels. In any event, keep in touch with this forum so that we know how you're doing and can provide more support.
Posts.Title: I'm desperately unhappy just now. jacquibutterfly dalycity

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 09:52PM beegirl wrote: I'm now 7-1/2 weeks past last chemo (hard to believe!) and have maybe a half-inch of hair. There was some even after the 2nd chemo, but it was always white or gray. In the past week, there's now some that's dark. Since I've colored my hair for I don't remember how many years, the dark hair is a surprise. I expect to keep waering my wig for quite awhile--I really like the style and color and don't find it too uncomfortable. I want to ask my stylist if she can make my own hair look like the wig! I was surpirsed today to discover that I actually have some hair on my lower legs--somehow I'd missed it! I guess I was expecting it to come in stubbly, but since I normally use an epilator on my lower legs, these hairs are thin and not really dark.  So I put the epilator to work. Also discovered armpit hair so use the electric shaver attachment on that. I seem to still have most of my lashes, but the one brow that wasn't thin already has become more sparse--of course, the white hairs that are out of line are still growing!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Title: Choosing a location for radiation therapy beegirl sharonw

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 08:29PM beegirl wrote: Nancy - thanks for the article. My onc specialized in bc at NCI before joining the private group next to VHC in December. I had a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy, plus I'm certain the hospital radiation oncology uses the latest equipment, etc. They may even have IMRT. Yesterday my onc told me that if she didn't believe I would get appropriate treatment here she wouldn't hesitate to send me elsewhere.    Sharonw - I'd been wondering where you were! Sounds like you've been doing lots of research. I'm not sure I understand how it works when you're on your stomach--is the radiation done from below? Given your early stage diagnosis, you've been hitting all the treatments. That's great that you can do it in 3 weeks, too. Let us know how it goes at NYU. I'm now set for my simulation at Arlington on May 13, about 3 weeks after my last TC chemo.
Posts.Title: Choosing a location for radiation therapy beegirl sharonw

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 02:24AM beegirl wrote: If you have a Whole Foods close by, you should be able to find a variety of calendula products. I'm using a honey-calendula cream on my one hand that developed red joints after tx #2 and so far after tx #3 the  redness hasn't returned.

Now that I'm finishing rads I'll ask her about getting it.

Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 09:18PM beegirl wrote: Rachel - I now look like you after just having my DH help me buzz off the rest of my hair. Who knew my head is so white! Di53- Sorry to hear about the chocolate. So far it still tastes okay to me, though not as intensely as before. I even bought myself a box of Entenmann's soft chocoalte chip cookies, which I've never before eaten! At 87 my mother says she's lost her taste for chocolate--I don't want that to happen to me! Grannie - I've found vitaminwater to be the most palatable, along with water. For the dry mouth I got some sugar-free cherry, pineapple and wintergreen candies from the stainedglasscandycompany. They have all kinds of flavors; they're  really good and help a lot. We each figure out for ourselves what helps! Hoping everyone has a good week!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 08:08PM beegirl wrote: Montazhnik: Thanks for the suggestion about making herbal tea to have to drink instead of water. I start chemo (TC) tomorrow and so far like the taste of water, but I might get tired of it. Right now I'm more worried about not being able to sleep tonight because of the steroids. The onc nurse returned my call about that and said it's okay to take Ativan. Best wishes to all others who are just starting this dance!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 07:41AM beegirl wrote: Grannie/Rose: I have my 2nd tx tomorrow. My hair started coming out some on Day 15 so I didn't want to wash it any more (and clog the drain). I wanted to wear my wig, but it wasn't comfortable with my hair underneath, so on Sunday, day 18, I went to a Hair Cuttery to get it cut short, but the stylist didn't understand me and made it too "nice." My DH went back with me and had another stylist buzz it to an inch long all over. As more falls out I'll just have my DH buzz it at home. I'm surprised how used to having such short hair I've gotten around the house, so don't always wear a scarf. Yesterday I wore the wig to work (10 hours total), and it was pretty comfortable. People's reactions are interesting. Even those who know about the b/c may not know that it's a wig. For others, I  just say I was ready for a change (I actually like the style better than my real hair so have to show it to my regular stylist!). The one thing that bothers me is that the top of my head is really sensitive and hurts a lot when touched. Anyone else experience that? It doesn't itch or ache otherwise. Do others have a hard time spelling words in their messages? I really try to re-read what I've written!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 11:46AM beegirl wrote: Thanks for the comments about the hair/head. I'm trying vitamin E oil on my head at night but not sure it makes a difference. C-Babe - thanks for your update--this too shall pass! Donnalee - I'll try your tip re: using tape--brilliant but so obvious!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 10:05PM beegirl wrote: Hi to all. I've worn my wig to work now for 3 days and the top of my head no longer is sensitive. I'm having fun telling those who don't know about my treatment that I was ready for a change (darker and no silver streak in front, which I've had since I was 18, and more of a longish pixie style). What I don't like is all the short hairs sticking to clothes and the inside of the wig, so I'm using packing tape to clean that and to rub over my head. Had 2nd tx this afternoon and was able to walk home again (about 3 blocks). However, I didn't sleep well last night because of the 2 steroids I took. My onc Dr said I should try tylenol PM next time, and I may take one tonight along with the stool softener/laxative. Sleep well!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 09:14AM beegirl wrote: Bridget - What a bummer! Get those docs to do what they can to help you!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 09:41AM beegirl wrote: mom2daughters: Thanks for your good wishes. I had 2 steroids 2x yesterday and take 1 2x day for 3 days; take Emend for nausea an hour before treatment, then for 2 days. Will get steroid, benadryl and anti-nausea today before the TC. I managed last night without taking an Ativan--had wine with dinner and a piece of chocolate cake at night! I was tired though my mind was awake for awhile; later I woke up when my elbow hurt when I unbent it (arthritis I think, though the steroids are supposed to help with that!). I'll have Neulasta the day after treatment. These posts really do help give us some idea of what to expect. For anyone getting just Taxotere and Cytoxan, there's a separate forum that's helpful. Cheers to all!
